To start off. If you want to play any type of comp in this game, you need to play on faceit. If you choose to play on CS2s servers: regular comp matchmaking or premier, you can expect 1-3 sometimes even 5 cheaters in almost every game. there have been stretches of games that I have played where I have gotten matched against cheaters in every single game. at this point it feels rare to get into a game of regular comp or premier and not be playing either with or against someone whos cheating, usually against. The worst part about this is that these cheaters will play the entire game legit and then when they start losing a lot, they will just start cheating to win rounds. At this point there are no cheaters being banned in this game aside from a handful of manual ban waves and there is still no anticheat. In CSGO, there was always a cheating problem but at least there was overwatch and VAC did at least something but now, Valve has just released this "new game" with very little to no "new content" that doesn't directly make them money through micro-transactions and gambling. In fact, if you look at it as a whole, this game has so much less as a whole than the game it is a "sequel" to. In CSGO there were more maps, gamemodes, and anticheats as well as other features that dont fit into those categories and now in CS2, the only different thing is the graphics are better (and strain your PC if yours is dogshit) and the gun play mechanics are slightly different and somewhat broken. I grew up playing CSGO and it has been my favorite game to just chill and do something fun and mindless and now this game is completely unplayable because whats the point? Think about it from my perspective GABEN, I sit there for a whole 40 minutes of repetitive gameplay just to have our game tied at 11-11. Suddenly, some dude on the other team decides to turn on his ecolocation skills and mysteriously always knows where we are and my team loses 13-11 and I have basically just wasted an hour of my life because from the start, my team was never gonna win. All that I am left to do is to sit there in shame, embarrassed I just wasted that time on such a dogshit game and all I am able to do is right click their name, report them for cheating, cheating, and cheating and click submit and never know if anything ever happens. Right now tho, I know for a fact that nothing is happening and just as a little slap in the nuts, a kick in the shaft, GABEN decided to quietly update the report feature so instead of being able to report something for cheating, cheating, cheating, and griefing at the same time, you now can only report someone for one of these things at a time which is such a small little spitting of into our faces as a playerbase that I would actually be embarrassed if I worked on this tiny feature update. It wouldve been one thing if it had always been that way and they just intentionally never changed it but the fact that they removed a feature that added convenience to the player is fucking crazy.
Gaben, go fuck yourself with a gold dildo from all the money you make off gambling degenerates.
Seriously go fuck yourself.

Pretty self explanatory. Result of when people working with VALVE who were in charge of authoring this nonsense tried to put LEFT 4 DEAD 2 into Counter-Strike: Source and this was the result. Ruined the entire series as a whole and honestly safe to highlight Counter-Strike 2 will undoubtedly follow suite sadly. 

Should have never happened how it transpired. For a new impressionable self absorbed generation who are guilty of the exact thing they propagate. Don't be fooled, on the surface it is appealing due to it's easy access, but this is horrible experience right down to the inherent lie it is reflective of skillful interaction relevant to acquired PC it is being run on. Expect to be brutally executed by own ally right off the bat no delay, no question asked, no remorse, no noteworthy concequence. Honestly this is exactly the type of thing a person would deserve even trying it. Not sure which snow globe they were peering into for this, but it doesn't fit the criteria of a positive envelope. There is no fixing this disaster

Entry shooter nobody should care about. CS2 for short is a Counter-Strike title for the poor. Garbage, a burning dumpster fire. False sense of manifesting zero to nil talentless first person skill coupled with it is designed for people with severely disabled cognitive functioning. On the surface it seriously appears to be 100% legit the next best thing or iteration fueling the series, far cry in reality. 

Once the hard truth sets in, it is fully realized. Don't judge a book by it's cover. 

Only got a few hours of online queue interaction across a period of several years throughout it's developed cycle including it's content, however this is definately enough to suffice knowing it is pure and utter suffering even being a better opponent. Absolutely no ties to either Source or Counter-Strike which both do the style far better even to it's evolved now counterpart Counter-Strike 2 which only just hit the ground running to immediately crash and burn in direction. Everybody is a CT, because being the Terrorist faction is absolute suicide

Design looks ugly, despite being technically newer and the round announce audio is an abysmal nightmare. This is commonly marketed by budget vendor display tech as the ideal competitive benchmark, despite it does the TEAM-FORTRESS 2 inhereted cosmetic skin store worse, which shouldn't even be possible. Anything good they've incorporated such as the Scope Focus or the new playstyle is entirely weighed down by the fact it just isn't a very good experience. Only peg leg structural integrity support holding this continually collapsing skyscraper up is the weird crosshair which at this point is part of the appeal trickery. Movement is floaty, the shooting is weirdly all over the place except for the power weaponry which is even more blatantly in control of the entirety of every round which no question will lose in actual stakes. Pretty sure by now it's so concretely embedded into the community there is no will left to change it to a significant degree in which is desperately required to revive the series. No idea what they were thinking with this, as it hit an all time high of desperate attempt forced spoonfeeding. Queue up, to be ranked in a reoccurring, never ending, revolving door, spinning world rotating plane of land theory of predictable treachery with nothing to show for it except useless digital currency. Bullpup has a terrible 3D field of view scope, yet is worse than using the tried and true no scope crosshair increase previously seen. Tried to resurrect first iterations of player acceleration as if they were good or worth keeping, but scrapped animations, viewmodels, and formula. Source already had years of backlash for altering a few numbers of AK-47 output in relation to Armor Protection. Just pointing out now, if people are still being recommended this nonsense by a so called ally, should just hit the Block and Report button and never speak to them about anything ever again. Help people acknowledge how foolhardy they are for wasting their life trying. Don't forget to be the one who pulls the trigger first as fast as the nervous process will allow in relation to tick rate and latency vendor preference. Already forgot, nullified for the intended result, here let me help. Here, let me get that. Don't worry, got it. How was that?

- Closed the game and Never touched it again.

MM in Comp is super bad, too many unranked players get mixed together, there's too many players there that had high ranks before the reset and it basically hinders "bad" players to even get a low rank simply because wins are so rare ... 

I was Silver 3 in CS:GO and had a WR of about 50-55%; I've played about 30-50 hours since CS2 dropped and I'm still unranked, still stuck with the other unranked players of highly various skill level... WR is way below 30%.

Not winning isn't the problem ... the issue is the MM experience is so inconsistent and when you commit to a competitive game it's really annoying when from warm up it's clear that this will be a loss because there's 2 ex Gold Nova players in the enemy team and you have Doofus and Dimwit with you.

It simply isn't fun anymore.

The successor to CS:GO, taking up the same Steam appID to preserve game time and reviews while also unfortunately replacing the achievements. Much of the CS:GO content is lost or limited for now in this new version.

Improvements:
Improved graphics, new competitive ranking with premier game mode, weapon buy back at the start of the round, new smoke mechanics, map-based competitive ranking, and custom placement of weapon stickers.

Issues:
1. Cheating has never been worse, no overwatch system for community based bans.
2. Missing maps, game modes, commands, overwatch, and achievements.
3. Map based competitive ranking requires 10 matches per map which is ridiculous. A hybrid ranking system is needed to reduce the number of matches needed to rank.
4. North America region ranking is broken.

Most of this reviews can be summarized with the following points:

Replacing CS:GO entirely and not allowing players to have CS:GO on their Steam library like 1.6 & Source.

Poor optimization, stutters, FPS drops and crashes. Bad performance on mid to low end gaming PCs.

No Mac Support, so Mac gamers who bought CS:GO can't even play.

Forcing everyone to play an unfinished version of CS2 that still feels like a beta.

Removing content from CS:GO like: maps like Cache, Train & Cobble, Danger Zone, Wargames, Workshop maps, community servers, no factions, missing commands...

Updated graphics: Some love 'em, some say they ruin the original aesthetic of the game and that it looks "too cartoony".

Broken skins, some players hate the new looks.

Overall dislike with the new "subtick" system which is mostly defined as a "laggy, unpolished experience" and a bunch of other nasty words you could read yourself by scrolling down the reviews.

Issues with lower ping users trying to kill high ping users and viceversa.

Game was shipped as a "full release" though it didn't bring anything new: no new cases, no new operation or gamemodes, no new cooperative missions, no new maps (asides from 3 reworks), no new anything. Players criticize that the "full release" is lackluster and barely adds anything new, in fact, it removes more features than adding anything.

Players are also mocking the new "tutorial" for being rather obsolete and not teaching enough to new players.

People compare it to Overwatch 2 and how mismanaged that game was by Activision-Blizzard-King, replacing Overwatch entirely and killing it's essence.

Overall people are unhappy because the game clearly needed more development time yet it was forced to release and replaced CS:GO entirely with rather less features and barely anything new.

As someone who has 1,500+ hours across CS:GO and CS2, I would NEVER recommend this game to anyone. Not only is there a substantial lack of anti-cheat measures, but also an astoundingly impotent level of support for it and the cheater problem that plagues it. Valve curbed the problem to a degree with Prime Status back in the day, but cheats are so advanced and easy to generate nowadays that it's basically spelling out the death of multiplayer gaming. 

I really couldn't express with words how disappointing it has been giving this game (and Valve) the benefit of the doubt, day in and day out. If I could refund my time, I certainly would. Don't waste your own time and sanity on this trash heap of an experience, because Faceit won't even save you.

Sure, the game itself is great, balanced, whatever, but like most other things in life, the company you keep (or rather, the company you're forced to be kept with, in this case) is far more important than the game itself. For me personally, it's generated one of the most lackluster and depressing experiences I've ever had the displeasure of having to go through, and that says a LOT.

TL;DR stick to single player or co-op games with friends, because at least in those arenas you don't have a risk of bumping into absolute fucking losers who have to pretend to be talented

Title: Counter-Strike 2: A Timeless Classic Reinvented

As a longtime fan of the Counter-Strike series, I couldn't wait to dive into Counter-Strike 2, and I can confidently say that it has exceeded all my expectations. Having played every iteration of the franchise since Counter-Strike Zero and Source, I can attest that Counter-Strike 2 is a true masterpiece and one of the best FPS games of all time.

What sets Counter-Strike 2 apart from its predecessors is its seamless blend of classic gameplay mechanics with modern enhancements. The core gameplay remains as addictive and exhilarating as ever, with intense firefights, strategic team play, and skill-based gunplay. From the iconic maps like Dust II and Mirage to the diverse selection of weapons and equipment, Counter-Strike 2 stays true to its roots while offering a fresh and immersive experience.

One of the most impressive aspects of Counter-Strike 2 is its attention to detail and polish. The graphics are stunning, with highly detailed environments, realistic weapon models, and smooth animations. Every map feels meticulously crafted, with strategic chokepoints, hidden corners, and destructible elements adding depth to the gameplay. Whether you're a seasoned veteran or a newcomer to the series, the level of immersion in Counter-Strike 2 is unparalleled.

Another highlight of Counter-Strike 2 is its robust multiplayer experience. The matchmaking system is fast and reliable, ensuring that players are matched with opponents of similar skill levels for balanced and competitive matches. The inclusion of ranked modes adds an extra layer of challenge and incentive for players to improve their skills and climb the ranks. Additionally, the community features, such as custom game modes, server browser, and workshop support, provide endless opportunities for players to customize their experience and connect with other fans of the game.

As someone who has spent countless hours playing Counter-Strike over the years, I can confidently say that Counter-Strike 2 is a worthy successor to the franchise. It captures everything that made the series great while introducing new elements that keep the gameplay fresh and exciting. Whether you're a longtime fan like myself or a newcomer looking for an adrenaline-pumping FPS experience, Counter-Strike 2 delivers in every aspect.

In conclusion, Counter-Strike 2 is a must-play for any fan of the FPS genre. With its addictive gameplay, stunning visuals, and robust multiplayer features, it sets a new standard for excellence in gaming. I've been playing Counter-Strike for years, and I can say without a doubt that Counter-Strike 2 is one of the best games in the series and a testament to the enduring legacy of the franchise.

CS2 REVIEW
tl;dr This game is good, but if you sometimes find yourself not having fun (long after you learned the mechanics), I can understand.

This game has already relatively the same upsides CS:GO has, so I won't talk about things like the gunplay, the basic mechanics, weapons, maps etc. unless there are significant differences in my subjective opinion.

The biggest downgrade of this game is that you have to win 10 matches to get a rank in each map, as well as winning 10 premier matches to get your ELO score... It takes many months to do that, unless you have no life. This makes the game much less approachable and if you're a fan of CS who would like to get other people to get what is so good about it, it's gonna be challenging.

A significant difference that makes CS2 stand from the rest in the frachise is the stability... and not in a good way. I can't count the amount of times I saw a player get disconnected because of a server related issue (because of how many times it happened). Meanwhile, the amount of times that happened in previous CS games was, like, less than 5.
The movement and the player colision is also janky as heck. Sometimes you bump into players, and other times you go right through them.
The netcode in general feels like it requires 5G or something, it's the only way I can describe it based on how I've seen every player treated.

The 2nd worse thing this game has is probably the matchmaking. Every match feels like a gamble, in which you bet some of your time (approx. 40 mins) to see if you will have a fun match or not. I'm not saying that you need to win to have fun, but a lot of times I lost, it was a stomp and that is surely not fun, at least in the matches played before getting a map rank. Imagine getting shot in the head by a running enemy... and I thought the AWP was a disgrace (I hate all sorts of instakills).

You will NEVER feel the sense of pride or accomplishment by this game, it's a game made for you to sink your time in, and you will never feel rewarded or fullfilled by (just) that. It theoretically should not be your goal, as a player. This game's true progress is ranking up, but that's only if this is what you aim for. As for me, I just wanna have fun each time I play, which is unfortunately not certain, mostly due to the matchmaking and/or the smurfs.
This game's matchmaking pool is a sea, with fish that are smaller and bigger than you, you just have to bet every time you queue which fish you play with & against. Premier, Comp and Wingman are just straight up you gambling your free time. It's still... relatively... worth it for the social experience, although the same applied to CS:GO too and I don't see a reason why CS2 is better yet.
I'm sure Valve works to make the game better in regards to servers, but with matchmaking, I'm not so sure...



CS:GO REVIEW
tl;dr This game is almost perfect. It's all fun and games until you die from an AWP shot too many times
I recommend playing in lower ranks only.

This game does a lot of important things right... and just a few things wrong.

In competitive, the only way to have fun is to win, because this game is NOT one of those that is fun enough to enjoy it even when you lose, unless you trick yourself into doing that (like me). In order to win, the key is to become at least average with the mechanical skill this game requires, but the most basic way to do that is to shoot only when you're still. Unfortunately, this means that Run & Gun is rarely a viable tactic (unless you're using an SMG in lower ranks). Camping is encouraged to a discusting degree, as well as headshots. Head is the only thing the enemies aim at (especially in average/high ranks, which is reasonable) and I just wish this didn't happen to such frustrating extent. When you die, chances are, the kill feed will mention it was a headshot. Lastly, spread is the reason you will most likely miss your shots. Even when you fire a pistol, if you use the firerate to its full degree, that will be the reason your shots didn't go where you expected them too. I wish this wasn't the case for a lot of pistols but here we are.

Unlike most, I simply enjoy the content the game has to offer, the guns, the maps, the modes and the social interaction (that may happen once in a while), which makes it sad for me that the only mode that is mostly getting attention by bot the devs and the players is competitive. Literally everyone plays competitively. Worst than that, people always tend to pick maps based on how well they know them, which means that new or fun maps can hardly become permanent additions. Heck, most maps that have been permanently added are maps that cater more to the try-hards. 
Not to mention, any other mode other than Competitive hardly gets updated, because people just don't care about fun apparently and all they want is Source 2 (fair enough), 128 tick servers and better anti-cheat. Like, I get it, 2/3 of these are important and reasonable to ask, but I believe there are other stuff worth mentioning too. Casual and other fun game modes are neglected. Competitive will never "die" because ranks are the reason people play this game, which is sad to see. There are game modes I wish had official matchmaking queues, like Fight Yard.

Talking about maps, this game used to be good at adding maps, until you become attached to a map, only for Valve to take it away from the official matchmaking. Multiple maps, like Santorini, Season, Tulip and Coast have been in and out of the game, sadly.

The AWP is getting it's own paragraph. Why? Because it's that awful to see an AWP in a match, especially if it's user is a skilled one. A sniper that can insta-kill if it shoots the head or the body? So, if you like getting eliminated, just because someone on the enemy team decided to save 4500$+, this is a game for you. No matter how good you are, you can't prevent an enemy from saving $. Insta-kill guns aren't fun to play against and despite being someone who has been a CS fan since 1.6, I can understand any newcomer's frustration on the AWP. I can tolerate CS:GO's AWP, but that's partially thanks to the fact that I don't see it that often, as well as it's mag capacity.

I would normally not recommend this game, at least until Valve added enough classic maps back in the game, and hopefully made proper changes to make the fun modes even better, and give players incentive to play a mode that isn't associated with a ranking system. However, an important reason why I easily choose this game over others is because of the massive amount of players in Competitive and the social interaction that comes with it, since people use voice chat, as well as the solid movement and shooting mechanics, which simply can't be found in other games and is too good to pass up. Despite this game not being a masterpiece, it is one of the best games out there, far better than most. Heck, the Source engine by itself is one of the best things that happened to the gaming industry.

I thought better of Valve than to think they would ever sink to Blizzards level and do a Overwatch 2 with their most loved title when they did much better with how they handled the Left 4 Dead series (even if L4D2 is theoretically superior to the first game in every way, they still kept the first one for the ones interested)
I'd love to return that model when "ending support" or "making a sequel" (both of which is perfectly natural for any developer), didn't automatically mean killing the game permanently because you're afraid it would compete with the remake.

This is not comming from me expecting permanent support. I would be totally fine if they never updated/promoted GO again, shut down all its servers (the game had perfect bot implementation and peer 2 peer hosting anyway) and moved the owned skins to a separate game (or made more valueable skins exclusvie to CS2) for those players who only played for the economy. The game was future proof until its mother betrayed it.
It never needed the facelift as CSGO looked better than most CoD games comming out 10 years after it. True artistic skill is making a game look amazing on a outdated engine with a timeless artstyle rather than spamming a bunch of GFX.

Even if CS2 might eventually be a great (or even better) game again in 10 years time, that defeats the entire purpose of making a "sequel" in the first place if youre just gonna break the foundation to get back where you were instead of just leaving it alone and moving on.
Just calling it "Counter Strike 2" makes no sense since that overlooks Condition Zero, Online and Source and if they refer to it being the sequel to GO then it makes no sense either since there now is no CS1.

Even the trailer is more soulless and pay no attention to the action, risk and thrill of CS and only highlights that "this is the new E sport money cow because we said so". 
A cinematic reimagening of playing a round on Nuke is replaced with a (incomplete) roadmap of features, a narrator pretending to care about history (when the game the trailer represents killed history) and a light hearted and colourfull ad that feels indifferent from any mobile game or toy commercial.

I must admit there are some few and small welcomed features (volumetric smoke is next to destructable environments the most mindblowing tech i never thought would ever be possible in games), but most of them dont even need Source 2 (like seeing your own legs or having honest crosshairs) or are swimming in a pile of garbage like annoying bloom/oversaturated lighting that makes Dust 2 look like a nuclear bomb has gone off (before the Terrorists even bought grenades) or make cs_italy dark and brownish in a ugly Fortnite colour scheme. The worst offender being the trolly HUD that blurred and opaqued the minimap so its harder to read & switched the positions of health and money just to be a jerk. (If it aint broke dont fix it! Change is only good if its a nessecary step for objective improvement!)
The game has also gotten harder to run. So much for accessibility in a even and competitive game. Wasnt much of a issue for me but i can imagen it will alienate a majority of the low end users or competitive players who thougt 120 frames on de_engage was too slow.

This is just disrespectful to any modder/mapper that has poured years of their life making content for this game or to anyone who values game preservation. The only reason i liked to play GO in the first place was the history behind it and the ocean of community crafted maps that are now incompatible and stuck in the trash bin.

RIP CSGO. I never liked you but i didnt want you to die for a bloddy VR engine in a irreversable update that only removed 10 years worth of content & polish and replaced them with new bugs and a game without legacy.
Unless there is a standalone mod that uses the last (good version) of the CSGO engine where i can pull my maps to im never playing this again. I refuse to update it or even aknowledge CS2 untill some modder or archiver provides a alternative. But i guess im the only person who cares about this and this was what the community (who probably just didnt want to admitt they hated spread or blame lack of skill on hit reg) wanted all along.
This is the second time Source 2 stole a game from me first by making the first half life game in 15 years VR exclusive and now by forcing me a "update" that i never asked or hoped for.

This is NOT a sequel but just the same game but with less than what we had before:
1. Less content (workshop maps and permanent alternative gamemodes like DZ removed)
2. Less polish. (Studdery movement, tilting glitch, exploits)
3. Less artistic dignity. (Gotta ruin player visibility and framerate by polluting the artstyle with expensive motion blur, screen tinting, bloom and lensflares. Its not like the rotten source engine is popular to this day just because it lacked annoying effects like this)
4. Less legacy. This is not the game i met my awesome friends in and not the same game i watched content creators grow in.
5. Less trust in valve to preserve their titles you paid for.
6. Less respect for the player.

A CS veteran's heartbreak ‚Äì this isn't Counter-Strike anymore

I've been playing CS since the 1.6 and Source days ‚Äì over 1,200 hours logged between the two. The raw gameplay, the gritty maps, the incredible community mods ‚Äì that was CS.  CS:GO was already a step in the wrong direction, and CS2 feels like they kicked the franchise while it was down.

Where's the modding soul? No custom maps, no crazy community servers? CS used to be a playground for creativity, now it's a sterile corporate product.

Microtransactions killed the vibe: Paying for weapon skins that used to be FREE community creations? Paying for map packs that would've been awesome workshop additions? It's insulting.

Gameplay feels... off: I can't put my finger on it, but the movement, the gunplay, it doesn't have that classic CS tightness. Like they tried to copy the "modern shooter" feel and ruined the formula.

No respect for the legacy: Where's the respect for the iconic maps, the old-school game modes, the history of this series? Feels like they just want to milk a familiar name.

Bottom Line:  If you loved the old-school CS, this ain't it. It's a soulless, cash-grabbing imitation that misses the whole point of what made Counter-Strike special.

I have mixed feelings about this game. It is often said that we play video games just to have a good time, disconnect and even make friends from other parts of the world. But, like everything in life, in csgo this changes. You can try to enjoy playing innocently with your friends but, without realizing it, you will start competing against them. You will soon find yourself at a mental crossroads where you will have to decide between winning the game or having a good time. You will never have it both ways. Your friends will betray you, even throwing grenades at you, blaming the enemy for their actions. Always look behind you. Never let your guard down, never turn your back even on the one who called you brother. And please, never stick your head out in palace trying to one-tap ct's awp. Become better than me.

[h1] Welcome to my analysis!![/h1]

[i]Let's start at the beginning![/i]

[b]What can we expect from this game?[/b]


[i]Fun, hours of gameplay, raids and new friendships. This game was made for people who like to challenge themselves and others. Its gameplay is not at all easy for people who are just starting to play CS:GO. You would need to spend a long time training to be able to do something useful in your team. However, even if you find it difficult at first, it may surprise you after a while.[/i]

[b]Does this game have a toxic community?[/b]


[i]And what game doesn't? Of course, for the most part the community isn't toxic, but it is toxic in a way. Sometimes you'll come across people who swear at you for no reason, or make fun of your nickname because they don't like it, or simply because you're gay or, in the minority, because you're a woman. Of course, this isn't generalized, it happens sometimes. I'm not here to rubbish the community, as I've seen it happen to other people and to myself in some matches.[/i]

[B]Is this a good game to pass the time?[/b]

[i]Yes, it is. Even though the style of play may seem cloying after a while, it won't let you down. There are several modes you can play with your friends, as well as competitive modes which, as the name implies, are for competing with other players. So you'd have plenty of things to do solo, as well as with your friends![/i]

[b]Does this game have a lot of hackers in it?[/b]

[i]Well, so far I haven't found any hackers in the games, but from what people in the community have been saying, there are some hackers in the game. This is because the game has recently become a free game, so because of this, many people who previously didn't want to hack the game because it was a paid game are now free to get in and strike terror in the game.[/i] 

[B]Is CS:GO Anti-cheat any good?[/b]

[i]As far as I can see, it is. It's made by valve itself, the creator of Steam. So, because it's from Steam, I think they take a harder line against the hacker community that exists within games.[/i]

[b]My rating for this game?[/b]

[i] I give it a 9.2. It's not perfect, but it's not so bad that it's unplayable. However, it's a lot of fun, you can make a lot of friends, among other things.[/i]

üí• Exciting Gameplay and Perfect Balance: Dive into the action as you choose your side ‚Äì will you be a cunning terrorist or a stalwart counter-terrorist? With meticulously crafted maps and strategic objectives, teamwork and tactical prowess are the keys to victory!

Title: Counter-Strike 2: A Comprehensive Journey Through Counter-Strike's Evolution

Introduction:
Counter-Strike 2 (CS2) marks the latest chapter in the storied Counter-Strike franchise, which has captivated gamers for decades. To fully appreciate the significance of CS2, we must first traverse the historical landscapes of its predecessors, including the groundbreaking Counter-Strike 1.6 (CS 1.6), the transitional Counter-Strike: Source (CSS), and the widely acclaimed Counter-Strike: Global Offensive (CS:GO). This comprehensive review delves into the intricate details of the Counter-Strike series, exploring its rich esports history, the allure of virtual skins, the evolution of operations, and the impact of map design on the gaming experience.

Counter-Strike 1.6: The Foundation of a Legacy:
CS 1.6 laid the foundation for the Counter-Strike phenomenon, emerging as a mod for Half-Life in 1999. Its tactical gameplay and tight gun mechanics quickly garnered a massive following, establishing the game as a mainstay in competitive multiplayer gaming. The grassroots esports scene began to flourish around 1.6, creating the blueprint for future iterations.

Counter-Strike: Source - A Transitional Phase:
Counter-Strike: Source, released in 2004, aimed to modernize the series with a new engine and enhanced graphics. While it faced initial skepticism from the dedicated 1.6 community, Source introduced dynamic physics and improved visuals, paving the way for the aesthetic upgrades seen in subsequent titles. The transition was not without controversy, but Source's impact on the series cannot be overlooked.

Counter-Strike: Global Offensive - A Resounding Success:
CS:GO, launched in 2012, was a critical turning point for the franchise. The game maintained the core mechanics of its predecessors while introducing updated graphics, new maps, and innovative gameplay features. CS:GO not only revitalized the series but also elevated Counter-Strike to unprecedented heights, becoming a cornerstone of the esports landscape.

Esports Evolution: Counter-Strike's Competitive Legacy:
The Counter-Strike series has been synonymous with esports since its inception. From local LAN tournaments during the 1.6 era to the global spectacle of CS:GO Majors, competitive Counter-Strike has evolved significantly. CS2 continues this tradition, building on the foundation of its predecessors to offer a competitive experience that resonates with both casual players and seasoned professionals.

Skins: Virtual Aesthetics and In-Game Economy:
CS:GO revolutionized in-game customization with the introduction of weapon skins. These virtual cosmetics not only added a layer of personalization but also created a thriving economy centered around skin trading and marketplaces. CS2 expands on this concept, introducing new, meticulously designed skins that add a fresh dimension to the virtual arsenal.

Operations in CS:GO: Dynamic Content Delivery:
CS:GO's Operations introduced a dynamic aspect to the gameplay experience. These time-limited events brought new maps, missions, and challenges, creating a cyclical pattern of engagement for players. CS2 continues this tradition, promising a stream of fresh content and keeping the player base invested in the evolving narrative of the game.

The Tapestry of Maps: A Crucial Canvas in Counter-Strike:
Maps have always been a cornerstone of Counter-Strike's success. From the iconic Dust II in 1.6 to the intricate layouts of CS:GO's Overpass and Mirage, each map has shaped the competitive landscape. CS2 inherits this legacy, introducing new battlegrounds that challenge players and foster strategic depth, ensuring that the dynamic nature of Counter-Strike persists.

Counter-Strike 2: The Next Chapter Unveiled:
CS2 emerges as the culmination of years of development, learning from the strengths of its predecessors. Building upon the legacy of 1.6, Source, and CS:GO, CS2 promises a refined gaming experience that caters to the diverse tastes of Counter-Strike enthusiasts. The anticipation surrounding CS2 is palpable, with the community eager to witness the next evolution in the series.

CS2 Esports: A Continuation of Legacy:
The esports scene surrounding CS2 is already taking shape, with tournaments and leagues adapting to the new title. The competitive integrity and strategic depth that define Counter-Strike are expected to thrive in CS2, ensuring that the game remains a linchpin in the global esports ecosystem.

Innovations in Skins: CS2's Aesthetic Frontier:
CS2 introduces an array of innovative skins, showcasing the evolution of virtual aesthetics. Collaborations between developers and the community result in unique designs that reflect the player base's preferences. The virtual skin market in CS2 is expected to further elevate the in-game customization experience, providing players with an expansive palette for personal expression.

Dynamic Operations in CS2: A Constant Evolution:
CS2 embraces the tradition of operations, introducing dynamic content that keeps the gaming experience fresh. These operations not only bring new challenges and maps but also serve as a testament to the developers' commitment to ongoing player engagement. CS2's operations promise a continually evolving landscape for players to explore and conquer.

Map Diversity in CS2: Balancing Tradition and Innovation:
CS2's map design strikes a delicate balance, incorporating beloved classics while introducing innovative battlegrounds. The goal is to create a map pool that caters to various playstyles, ensuring that CS2 remains accessible to both veterans and newcomers alike. The diverse range of maps in CS2 promises to be a key factor in sustaining the game's longevity.

CS2's Future: A Promising Horizon:
As Counter-Strike 2 unfolds, the future of the franchise appears promising. Ongoing support, potential expansions, and continued engagement with the esports community hint at a dynamic future for CS2. The developers' commitment to innovation and responsiveness to player feedback positions CS2 as a frontrunner in the ever-evolving landscape of competitive gaming.

Conclusion: CS2 - An Evolving Masterpiece:
Counter-Strike 2 encapsulates the essence of its predecessors while pushing the boundaries of what Counter-Strike can achieve. From the historical significance of 1.6 to the transitional phase of Source and the resounding success of CS:GO, CS2 emerges as a culmination of the series' rich legacy. With its commitment to esports, virtual customization, dynamic operations, and map diversity, CS2 stands poised to become a timeless masterpiece, ensuring that Counter-Strike remains a dominant force in the gaming world.

[hr][/hr] 
28/09/23 Update: I'm disappointed in Valve. First of all, you can no longer play CS:GO. Why? Why didn't you just release it as a new app? People still play CS:Source, so why not let us play CS:GO easily? You wiped things such as achievements from CS:GO in the process and it's just disappointing to see from a company as beloved as Valve. I'm guessing it'll be they wanted to keep skins and they wanted to keep the 1.6 million or something existing CS:GO reviews. The reason this annoys me so much is because CS2 isn't ready. It's buggy and still missing key features such as the workshop, the other game modes like arms race and danger zone as well as major maps that are used in professional tournaments like de_cache and de_train. This isn't even touching on the sub-tick shooting animation issues, where the animation has to wait till the next tick instead of happening at a sub-tick level for some reason? The whole game feels underwhelming for something that is supposed to be an upgrade from CS:GO. I didn't even touch on the terrible frame rate I'm getting, seriously, 80fps at 1080p medium on an RTX 3060? Bit of a joke. They should've taken Valve time, it's perfectly fine to delay the release of a game if it isn't ready.

Counter Strike 2 is basically a good game and I usually enjoy playing this game, but it also has strong weaknesses.
The anticheat system provided by "valve" is so bad that many players switch to third party servers such as "faceit.com" because they have significantly fewer or no cheaters.
In addition, it would be better to replace a player who has left the game with another player in order to compensate for the resulting disadvantage for the team, instead of letting the team play with one less player.

All in all you can love the game but hate it at the same time.
In my opinion, fixing the critique mentioned above would lead to a better gaming experience and fun.

In the revered arenas of CS:GO, where every flick shot is a testament to skill and strategy, I embarked on a quest as ambitious as a defuse under fire: the search for the elusive 'nude mod.' With the determination of a CT guarding the bomb site and the precision of a T executing a well-coordinated rush, I scoured every corner of the virtual battlegrounds in hopes of uncovering pixels stripped of their digital garments.

Yet, like a failed rush against a fortified defense, my efforts yielded no fruit. No matter how many crates I opened or how many custom servers I explored, the promise of nudity remained out of reach.

However, amidst the disappointment, I discovered something far more valuable: the sense of camaraderie shared among players, the exhilaration of clutching a round in the face of adversity, and the sheer joy of immersion in the vibrant CS:GO community.

While the game may lack in pixelated nudity, it more than compensates with the thrill of competition and the bonds formed through teamwork and shared experiences. So here's to CS:GO, where the real treasures are the friendships forged and the memories made on the digital battlefield.

Counter-Strike is a classic title in the first-person shooter genre that has managed to stay popular since its initial release in 2000.

However, despite it's enduring popularity; I personally do not enjoy the game. Let me explain.

The gameplay loop basically boils down to buying weapons and going into shootouts against an enemy team.
All of this takes place in a limited pool of maps - which are very much static and small.
You compete for virtual ranks that are designed to display your skill level in the game to others. You can also go for collecting skins for your weapons - though they are mostly random drops.
Unfortunately, toxic teammates that take the game way too seriously along with occasional cheaters take a lot away from the experience.
However, if you have a few friends that play the game casually every now and then - it can still be enjoyable.

This is a competitive game. Sometimes new maps are added and older maps are reworked or removed. But apart from some visual changes and some weapon balances, the game plays out pretty much the same as it did when it was first released in 2012.
Though, I do enjoy some of the changes. The HRTF sound system update, the Negev change and recently the changes brought in with Source 2 update are all nice changes that changed the game for the better in my opinion.

CONS:
- New dealt damage stats are visible only for about 5 seconds and only displayed after round ends, if you lucky enough to catch it as you might be watch something else while dead

- There is absolutely no way to track who hit you first, who last and who in between with the newly introduced dealt damage system

- You won't know the damage taken was done with what weapon. You just cannot know that no more.

- You will only get a summary of damage dealt at the end of round under enemy avatars, again for about 5 seconds

- It is very difficult to tell by avatar, who hit you from the players table (When pressing TAB). You have to scan by eye the entire players list, then find their avatar to associate with their name. It is so CONFUSING!!

- It sucks you can't develop any strategy based on above. At least I used to for the past 20+ years. I know, I am old, I grew up with this game. I also grew up with Atari. That was fun!

- Totally unacceptable for Valve to delete CS:GO and shove this garbage in our throats

- I always play with the XM1014 (Auto-Shotgun) the new one in CS2 sounds like a pistol, really Valve? You gonna do me like that. Is like one driving a ferrari but its exhaust system sounds like a little Honda Civic. 

- I actually paid close to $15.00 for CS:GO. Since the game is not in my library anymore, I feel robbed (I actually do). Sorry I did not asked to be updated to CS2. At least valve should return my money

- Smells like lawsuit to me. I mean, this should be illegal to take something away from you after one paid for it.

- Game has some performance issues, it has closed out on me on a few occasions. Never happened before with CS:GO


CONCLUSION:
-  I have been playing CS2 for few months now, I just can't get used to this dealt damage stats. I can't. It is plain stupid. I miss dealt damage in console feature every time I play. Games feels backwards, that's not an improvement. It's a drawback.

What was once my favorite game turned into a disappointment of a game. Firstly, the mechanics changed, nothing seems to work anymore. No matter what I do it seems like my bullets are going through the enemy instead of killing him which makes zero sense. Spray is ruined, A-D tactic (shooting while pressing A-D) won't work anymore, even the AWP, which was the only gun I believe I had some skill with, doesn't seem to work. 

Premier is a bad idea. Why would I compete for a place on a stupid top. Other than that, premier is full of cheaters. Half of the top are cheating and the anti-cheat is worst than it was on CS:GO (I never thought that can happen). Competitive still exists but now you have a different rank for every map, which ruins the whole point of it. Why would I wanna be silver on Dust and Global on Mirage? I WANNA BE GLOBAL EVERYWHERE IF I'M GLOBAL RIGHT? Oh btw, there isn't a single player that is ranked higher than Legendary Eagle Master when I'm writing this. They ruined it so bad. 

When it launched there were a lot of bugs, fps drops and lag for most of the players. It seems that they fixed that, for now at least.

I was so hyped when they finally announced Counter-Strike 2 just to end up with a half finished game that nobody likes.

After falling back in love with CS again after CS2 launched, the game has gotten more and more unstable with each update. Every bugfix spawns 5 more ridiculous bugs and it feels like Valve don't have a QA team working on this game at this point. The latest ridiculous bug is now kicking players from competitive games for 'teamkilling' when they're really killing the enemy players. It sounds made up but this is a real bug. Unfortunately it's just one of many introduced in the latest patch. Other gems include grenades sticking in thin air and extreme lag when scoping. All this in a minor patch! You can only begin to imagine how many 'features' they cram into the major patches,

The ranking system is borderline unplayable, if you try to queue with mixed elo friend groups the outliers will get shafted as the ranking system will essentially try very hard to equalise everyone to the same rating over time. Similarly bad players will obtain astronomical ratings by playing with 4 friends. In a game where no one's rating even remotely reflects their skill, good luck finding balanced matches. Not to mention that since the game is still horribly unstable you're going to be playing a decent number of matches 4v5 as your teammates will crash out the game and occasionally not be allowed to reconnect to the server.

After losing 4 matches in a single sitting to having teammates who are AFK, teamkilling, crashing repeatedly, being kicked for "teamkilling" when not actually teamkilling, or a combination of these, I've decided not to waste anymore of my time on this game and have uninstalled, gg volvo. Maybe catch you for CS3 but I doubt it.

EDIT: lol I reinstalled after 24 hours fml

This game is a masterpiece of realism. You can experience the thrill of being a counter-terrorist or a terrorist in various scenarios. You can also enjoy the realistic physics of bullets, grenades, and knives. The game is very balanced and fair, except for the hackers, smurfs, griefers, toxic teammates, and Russians. The game also has a great community of friendly and helpful players, who will always give you constructive feedback on your performance. The game is very addictive and rewarding, especially when you rank up or get a rare skin. The game is also very cheap and affordable, only costing you your sanity, dignity, and social life. 10/10 would recommend.

(This is my first time reviewing a game so please don't judge the game too hard after reading this) Counter-Strike 2 is pretty much the only game I play on Steam as of now. Would 100% recommend. The player-base is still solid after the switch over from CS:GO. Prime upgrade is pretty much a must-have if you want to enjoy the game. I've had prime now for a couple months and even though the competition is higher, there are few to no cheaters in my lobbies. Cheaters aside, there is a fairly sharp learning curve to this game, but after some practice it becomes a great game to play. The Steam market for CS-2 is also another interesting aspect that I've only dabbled in by selling the weekly cases for a little money to buy skins. If you enjoy team vs. team, somewhat skilled games, this is an easy must-have.

Title: CS2: A Disappointing Sequel

Rating: ‚òÖ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ‚òÜ

As a longtime fan of the original CS game, I was eagerly anticipating CS2. However, my excitement quickly turned to disappointment upon playing it.

Firstly, the graphics are a massive step backward. While the original CS had a gritty and immersive aesthetic, CS2 feels like a cheap knockoff with bland textures and uninspired character designs. It's as if the developers put no effort into updating the visuals for a modern audience.

The gameplay mechanics are also lackluster. Controls are clunky and unresponsive, making it frustrating to navigate the game world. The AI of enemies is laughably bad, often standing still or running into walls instead of posing any real challenge. It's clear that little thought went into refining the gameplay experience.

Furthermore, the story is nonsensical and poorly written. Unlike the original CS, which had a gripping narrative that kept you engaged from start to finish, CS2's plot feels like a disjointed mess with gaping plot holes and underdeveloped characters. It's impossible to become emotionally invested in the story when everything feels so poorly executed.

To add insult to injury, CS2 is riddled with bugs and glitches. From game-breaking crashes to physics-defying animations, it's clear that the developers rushed the release without properly testing it. It's unacceptable to release a game in such a broken state, and it shows a blatant disregard for the players who spent their hard-earned money on it.

Overall, CS2 is a massive disappointment and a stain on the legacy of the original CS. It fails to capture the magic of its predecessor and instead serves as a reminder of everything that can go wrong with a sequel. Save your money and steer clear of this trainwreck of a game.

As of writing, it has been 7 years, and this video is still completely relevant to CSGO.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q9RjDRLBWio
That's a problem.

This game is horribly unfun and tedious. You're not playing it because it's skillful, varied, competitive, or fun. You're playing for the barely legal skin stock market attached to it to make money from the textures Valve sells on fake guns like NFTs and crypto, but without the real world usage of crypto, and all of the make-believe usage and regret of NFTs.

Everything you loved about CS, whether it be the goofy and casual multiplayer, the great presentation, variety of unique maps and modes, satisfying weapons, fun physics, iconic sounds, fast-paced gameplay, or even the charming juvenile artsyle from CSS and 1.6 has been stripped down heavily, replaced, or removed with exactly one exception.

And the game is incredibly anti-fun because 20 people in a competitive tournament have fun for more than 2 seconds with this game once a year in some country you don't know the name of because they found some slightly broken gun or strategy by accident and now it's going to be nerfed or removed.

(They don't actually have fun, they just want the money. Listen to any one of them for 2 seconds, and they sound burnt out and exhausted. Just ask Summit1g.)

No experimentation, no fun strategies, no weird or cool new game modes, no fun or interesting maps for more than a month maybe when there's a new operation, and Valve wonders why everyone still plays Dust 2 like the lab rats they've conditioned their players into being. 

Maybe if your game is made with the most basic and repetitive gameplay for 12 year olds on their grandma's laptop, you should expect that. It actively encourages people to play like reckless idiots on the worst map because your punishment for playing well is playing the horrible game more and being blamed for losing when you die from nowhere.

Maybe you would at least provide some of kind of reward or sense of progression for playing it, right? Well if you count some jpeg you can spray on a wall 50 times that's worth a penny as a reward, then you should just go play a better game. People complain about Call of Duty, but that game is the best selling yearly for a reason.

A lack of progression and rewards give you nothing to show for your time. And the game has actively had many changes targeted at making it less fun when it's far too simplistic to even matter. 

R8 Revolver, sniper scope nerfs, movement is slow and clunky, customization options are just paywalled features from older games but worse, new features they do add are horrible and manipulative. It's all been scientifically made to be worse and make you spend more time and money when nothing is there.

So if anything you can think has been made worse or removed to make money, what does this game do well? Exactly one thing, the story.

CS was not known for its story, but when Valve released Operation Wildfire in 2016, they added a cool coop campaign. It's not even remotely close to Left 4 Dead or Portal 2 coop, but it was a genuine improvement over Condition Zero Deleted Scenes that was somewhat relevant to the rest of the game.

Here it is:
https://youtu.be/xqvOuVd2Ysw

When I played Condition Zero Deleted Scenes, it became pretty clear to me that it was stripped down, pretty generic, and lost in translation between 5 developers who never finished any one of their games. Valve added a neat coop mode that had you doing basic, but fun objectives with easter eggs and little rewards.

This coop multiplayer story hybrid is something that no one has ever done well, and it unfortunately was another case of that, looking more like a hacked together coop mode that a couple modders would put on the workshop. But compared to Condition Zero, this is a welcome improvement.

I would think a multiplayer shooter would have some multiplayer in its story, and a 2 player coop mode is a great way of doing this. However, I don't think this is the highest priority for Valve, seeing how long a second coop campaign took to release.

Check the date on the second video here.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RdS3un_Z3Zc

A live service game should always be adding new content as opposed to removing it. And be doing so frequently to keep you playing. The only times CSGO adds anything is when it's unfun, so anyone aside from those attending competitive events yearly are benefiting from these stupid decisions.

Games are supposed to be fun first and foremost. And with this in mind, I cannot actively recommend this game to anyone with all of its issues, and terrible anti-fun first attitude. You should not be judged as worse or punished for trying to have fun playing any game, and Valve knows it.

As Valve themselves will say: 

"Any system that generates revenue at a cost of customer happiness is a broken system we need to fix."

And after 10 years, it should be clear they'll never fix it. Attitude reflects leadership, and that's something no update or patch will ever fix. Cannot recommend. 

https://youtu.be/L1QE6ogmSkw

CS2 Update:

They removed most of the game. I guess they turned up the color saturation now. That's about it. 

So the one excuse I had playing this game is gone. No more arms race, deathmatch, or other casual modes. To be fair, every call of duty does them all better anyway, so if you really want to play this bad game, even when Valve doesn't want you to, just go to the Betas and select the [Demo_Viewer] version. It's really not worth your time, and calling it a tactical game is stupid.

It's an arena game with low health and bad guns, difference is that Counter Strike Source is $10 and you can't pay me to play this. Plus they also screwed over their core audience of people with bad pcs and laptops. So good luck playing it now. I'm going back to Payday 2, later.

Arms race update:
So I saw Valve added arms race back in, but I don't even know why they bothered because they only have 2 maps and both look like an Unreal Engine 4 game from 2015. If you're going to piecemeal the game I originally purchased in 2015 back to me, could you at least have the common courtesy of making sure all the old maps are in there? "Remastering" two maps that are equal to shipment in COD4 is not some hard work of art, it's literally just a texture pack. And not even a good one, I might add.

Let's put more effort examining them than Valve did "remastering" them. Shoots now has no sniper cover, and the map has worse visibility than CSGO. They also removed the cool rain and pirates. Baggage added a ton of ladders and walkways so you can spawncamp even more than before. Now you can get on top of a vent and ambush both sides while having cover from the garage door. And instead of looking like a real life airport, it looks like a generic Overwatch map. St. Marc, Monastery, Safehouse, and Lake are gone.

This game is larger than the sun, so rather than tell you about it, I'll tell you about my experience with it.

I began playing Counter-Strike in 2005 with CS 1.6. I watched Wisenhunt and cut many old habits from shooters like Halo using long practice sessions and much research. I found internet cafes that hosted local competitions and placed in the tops on all of them. I got down more than a few times going into a higher level of play. Learned discipline, sportsmanship, and respect. I worked my way through the professional scene into national competition, and only once landed into internationals.

My Global Offensive rank is Silver Elite as of this review.(Supreme Master First Class before the 'Great Elo Shift')

I will wholly recommend this game for anyone who wants to learn the basics of competitive shooters, have a good time, and make new friends.
I will never recommend this game as a professional competitive environment without utilizing a third party system.

Valve is an entirely different company, and this game is no longer a Counter-Strike game in my view. So many updates down the pipeline of this former Source console port has seen it deteriorate into a fully accessible CS Clone with many issues.

Let's begin with proper configuration to play this game in any semblance of professional play.
Block https://blog.counter-strike.net from your network
The ingame widgets drag anywhere between a few kb's to 100MB/s from your network and stay on even during a match
Use custom configuration maps or files to remove in-game bloat
Change your entire game options tab to suit what anyone in the game would actually use (Why would default be anything other than 1???)
Then hopefully you've paid your way into competitive, or you're in for some of the nastiest third world country behavior you've ever seen on your road to arbitrarily rank a different leveling system than you'll ever pay attention to for the rest of your life, outside of once a year for a participation trophy (or way more colors of said trophy if you play 24/7).
You'll be very naive to believe you can play this game solo, especially without Prime. In the end if you want to be serious, they will take your money, and your data as you'll have to fork your phone number out to another ripe internet repository to be stored indefinitely whilst you play.
As a previous iteration user, you'll find controls are never as responsive, spread is rampantly enforced now, and you'll be placed with anyone between an equivilent to complete noobs to professionals all in the area of around 4 ranks as the 'Great Elo Shift' mentioned previously has taken full affect in bringing some of the worlds strongest players to the end of Silver rankings whilst complete imbeciles are still amongst them as well. You can no longer use skillful strategy, as shots are left entirely to chance, noone else knows to lower their latency by blocking the CS blog, and everyone has an entirely skewed idea of what "skill" even looks like.
this is where I have to say. for the set of users like myself that helped build an entire community around Counter-Strike...
Press Uninstall, and enjoy Source.

_Edit: CS:2 largely fixes a lot of this.

/// Below this is my original CS:GO review, left up for posterity.

CS:GO is a highly competitive skill-based first-person shooter that will eventually pay for itself in skin and sticker drops. Tons of game modes both casual and competitive and deep gameplay make it hard not to come back a few times a week. You can sell drops on market for a few pennies for junk up to bigger chunks of cash for popular or high-quality weapon and knife skins.

This game regularly goes on sale for as low as $3.75. If you're only a casual player, that might be the price to shoot for. If you're looking for a competitive shooter to sink more time into, even full price is gonna be worth it.

The CS2 hype was real, the player-base was stoked and the community expected the bare minimum when it came to a stable release from Valve. 

The CS2 we got and the there lack off proper updates is deplorable; from basic game mechanics and movement being ruined and changed for the worse to the so called "sub-tick" system where those with lower ping and higher frames get the advantage in nearly every situation. What you see, isn't what you get as peaker's advantage is still a huge issue while your own bullets are seemingly whiffing through enemy player models and sprays feeling like an inconsistent mess. 

The ranking system on competitive mode is beyond skewed, for reference; once being global doesn't mean anything in CS2, starting ranks will nearly always be silver and good luck getting out of it. Silver in CS2 is more likely anywhere from Nova to GE on CS:GO from the games I've experienced, and without a pre-made team you gamble to end up with either players with sub 50 hours and no experience to over 5k hour try-hards. You're better off playing Premier which has it's very own massive flaw just like standard competitive; cheaters.

Cheating is now more rampant than I've ever seen in CS:GO, every other premier game has either a closet cheater, a full blown cheater with a fresh account and (possibly) smurfs with barely any playtime. Demos are being 'corrupted' left and right and there is still no Overwatch, VAC is banning those with DPI switch buttons on their mouses instead of those that actually full blown cheat and that doesn't bode well considering VAC-Live was expected by many to actually function. Don't let A.I fix your game. FIx it yourself. Get a part of the team actively snooping out cheat development and counter it instead of recreating an already outdated trash anti-cheat that doesn't work.

Valve likes us players to think they're doing something for the game but, adding old content back in after 4 months, dropping a new case with a shiny new knife and only updating the game when a Tournament is actively going on to casually fix some minor things won't solve the larger issues this game faces and unless they start working on actually improving the game and fixing the mess they created this game will continue to lose it's actively dwindling player-base. 

I hate being so negative about a game I used to be so passionate about, but CS2 has let me down massively. Each time I play I'm reminded on how good CS:GO was compared to what we got now. Yes graphically the game is great but, in my humble opinion, it wasn't for the better considering the trade-off we got; good ol' CS:GO replaced for a beautiful but, buggy mess filled with cheaters.

Yes I prefer it to CS:GO purely since I almost never feel like the shot I just took before I died, was discounted, which I assume is what the sub-tick rate is for, of course I now I have nothing to blame my in game deaths on!
But seriously it is surprising how this makes the game far less tilting / frustrating to play. 

I do miss arms race because that was my warm up, before competitive and casual is no substitute because even with lower ranked players you are going to die in arms race, which is not the case in a causal game.

I was toying with the idea of using retakes for warm up instead, which is also not present in CS2 (at least just now) but those really long to get achievements were keeping me with arms race (Never will have the chance to get them now).

Hope they at least bring back these two modes and I would not mind all the other missing modes too.

Only very real negative would be the Premier matchmaking, which is great until you get to a rank up match. This is were it falls down, People disconnect from matches or you are paired with people who seem to have never played the game before and even when I carry a match (rare but it happens) its not enough to actually win the match. I will say if you have a five stake am I sure it is absolutely super to play this mode. However, I think they need to tweak the solo queue players to have a more even match at this point - even match of 10 people on a rank up game would better (salty but better).

Lastly the ranks per map for competitive mode actually seems like a really good idea, though it does take ages to get a rank especially if you are like myself and play all the maps in turn (remove a map each time I play it until all maps have been played and then re-queue them all again, etc.).

Anyway that is my opinion of the game to date. Hope it helps someone out there.

Addendum: I attained a rank on Dust II and just had my first game with other ranked players and it felt just like a game should feel playing amongst the correct skill level of players, I was the lowest rank and if felt like it. Its just getting to the rank on each map that is going to be a age to achieve. I think it would be better to have a matches to get an overall rank on every map you played first and then after that it would change to ranks per map, just to get over the getting a rank hurdle.

Community is not very helpful or patient with beginners.
The CS2 Update nuked the unranked normal game mode, so there's no way for a beginner to learn playing the game in a realistic environment. You're forced to play either the competitive Premier mode, in which you only get assigned a skill group after winning 10 matches, or the generic ranked mode in which, again, you need to win 10 matches on each map to be assigned the respective map's skill group.
Since you're matched up against players with thousands of hours of experience until you get a skill group, you're probably going to lose a lot more than you win. This leads to you having to play a frustrating amount of games with unfair skill disparities between teams.
There's not even a lot you can learn from playing against much better opponents other than "Guess I should aim better." and "Maybe I shouldn't have been here.".
On top of the enemy probably ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• on your head every game, your team mates will flame and even kick vote you out of the game if your performance can't keep up with the rest.
You really need a thick skin if you want to pick this game up as a solo player, especially when this is your first FPS game.

I use to love this game, I use to come home from work and jump on CS and jam until I went to bed. These days the game is full of hackers, and when you aren't contending with hackers then you contend with random lag spikes that make no sense in the game, and if its not the lag and its not the cheaters that get you, then its the terribly optimised maps! 

Why my GTX2070 has frame drops on Overpass and Ancient every time I am around water... hell only the devs will know... weirdly my brother WITH THE SAME graphics card and almost identical setup has no issues.

And when I finally decide that its time to play a premier then I am greeted with toxic team mates who in round one call "NO ONE LOVES YOU, NO ONE CARES FUCK OFF AND DIE" then I am only left to wonder why I even started playing this game again?

The developers clearly do not care about the cheating problem, it really is an easy fix, but only they will know why they wont address it. Maybe the cheater problem is bigger than we all think and if Valve actually does something about it then we may realise that there are only about 500 of us in the world who plays legit?! Who knows.

All I know is that after 4 600 hours. I am done with this game, its not worth investing the time in this anymore. I will rather go off to Valorant where the anti cheat actually works. WHICH IS A FUCKING PAIN because no one wants agents with 'special abilities' but you know what, I would rather contend with that than the constant cheaters in CS2!

We all know what Tetris is: an unassuming puzzle game involving the manipulation of falling blocks; yet within this mild-mannered game is there encoded undertones of communist political thought? Could Tetris be a covert ploy fomented by the former USSR to distribute Communist propaganda throughout the western world? Is Tetris truly what it would appear to be or is it in fact the most successful subterfuge of the twentieth century?

I seek to prove that Tetris is in fact a simulated microcosm of the philosophy of Marx and Engels, a clever encryption of the penultimate revolution to be held by the proletariat at the expense of the bourgeoisie. 

To begin I must typify who the players of this Marxist melodrama are. The player serves as a member of the bourgeoisie, perhaps a wealthy factory owner or a land baron, and the falling blocks which litter the screen are representations of the proletariat. Nameless and faceless, the anonymous members of the proletariat are sacrificed at the altar of capitalist greed by the bourgeoisie player whose only goal is to convert his proletariat pawns into capital, as represented by the player‚Äôs score. Now this score is truly meaningless, an ethereal measurement of wealth accrued at the expense of others for no other purpose than to elevate the player‚Äôs ego and to serve as a means of comparing how well one member of the bourgeoisie does in relation to another. This is capitalist one-upsmanship at its finest. ‚ÄúDamn the expense so long as I have more than anyone else,‚Äù what a comforting philosophy to be fostering among today‚Äôs youth.

However, the player cannot gain wealth perpetually. Just as in Marxist doctrine the revolution of the proletariat is inevitable; eventually the player will make a mistake in his or her manipulation of the proletariat and the player will pay for it, dearly. The proletariat will rise up. Uniting as one the working-class blocks build ever higher, ascending to the bourgeoisie throne and casting down the player, the proletariat seizes the means of production and the reigns of government. Game over.

This end is inevitable, the Revolution cannot be stopped; it can only be postponed. No matter how skilled the bourgeoisie is no amount of cajoling, bribery, or intimidation will save them. The player will lose, always. The only comfort to the disenfranchised player is the hard-lost score, a miniscule, meaningless number, the only testament to their struggle and a taunting reminder of their former glory.

How to Fix CS2: 

1. INTRUSIVE ANTI CHEAT 

2. 128 tick, if subtick must stay, provide definitive proof that it is better. For anyone wondering 
     why the gun play feels so bad (though not the only reason) Valve scaled down the spray 
     patterns for weapons, the reason being "it will make it feel more like 128 tick" oookay.. so 
     Valve says back in GO the patterns were vastly different between 64 tick servers and 128 
     tick, just blatantly talking out of our asses now aren't we Valve? Main reason for 
     confronting this, being that if subtick is so much better than 128 tick ever could be, why are 
     we trying to get it as close as we can to 128 tick and failing at it too? Subtick is just another 
     way of saying: Here at Valve we are cheap bastards and will NOT invest our endless cash 
     flow into better servers for the player base that is the source of that cash flow in the first 
     place. Classic capitalistic bullshittery, If your company is making profits make sure to never 
     give back, cut costs, and sacrifice quality at every turn.
      
3. Fix peekers advantage and overall player model movement speed.
     a. Actually align your hit boxes with your animations. 
     b. Drastically reduce the run n' gun/ jumping while shoot accuracy. (for all weapons)
     c. Eliminate the dramatic player model sway from side to side/ back to front. 

4. Go through the laughably small map selection you brought to the table on your over hyped 
    rushed release, and actually clip edges and angles. (lets not wait forever like pit on dust 2 
    in GO, before all the maps started to get a fresh update back in 2016)
     a. Add more maps (ones that fit the fundamentals of CS)
     b. Drastically reduce the lighting and shadow effects, they are super cool I like the engine 
         and its capabilities, however this use of lighting does NOT fit competitive play. 
     c. Remove Ancient, it fundamentally does not fit CS. Mid is a fuster cluck, the rest of the 
         map is a series of narrow funnels onto sites with too many angles to clear, and nowhere 
         to sensibly rotate in any timely manor, etc.

5. This is a simple one Valve, are you ready? I swear its not rocket science, you may want a 
     pad and pen though. Okay here we go..  Make the guns do the correct damage, especially 
     through objects and certain materials. Its like you guys lost all the data you had on 
     ballistics and are just winging it at this point, it has been stated that CS:GO was just ported 
     over to Source 2, did anyone even attempt to check and dare I say double check anything 
     at all?

6. Fix the economy.

   
  CS2 development team really could just keep sitting around being useless fuckers with 
  mounds of cash to blow up their own asses, or they could have some self respect and pride 
  in their work for once. 
  Now the whole dev team sits there and disregards everything because they've now been 
  bullied about it. Truth is I'd praise you if you did anything worth a shit lmao.

Counter-Strike 2 builds upon the foundation of its predecessor, delivering an exhilarating and refined experience for fans of tactical first-person shooters. Developed with meticulous attention to detail, this sequel introduces a host of new features and enhancements that elevate the gameplay to new heights.

One of the most notable additions is the expanded arsenal of weapons, offering players a diverse selection to choose from, each with its own unique characteristics and handling. Whether you prefer the precision of a sniper rifle or the rapid firepower of an assault rifle, Counter-Strike 2 caters to various playstyles, ensuring every encounter feels fresh and engaging.

In addition to the revamped weaponry, the game introduces innovative maps that are intricately designed to promote strategic gameplay. From tight corridors to expansive outdoor environments, each map presents its own set of challenges, requiring teams to communicate effectively and adapt their tactics accordingly.

Furthermore, Counter-Strike 2 introduces a robust matchmaking system that ensures balanced and competitive matches. Whether you're a seasoned veteran or a newcomer to the series, the game offers a welcoming environment for players of all skill levels to test their abilities and improve their gameplay.

Visually, Counter-Strike 2 impresses with stunning graphics and immersive environments that draw players into the heart of the action. From detailed weapon models to lifelike character animations, every aspect of the game is polished to perfection, delivering a cinematic experience that is second to none.

Overall, Counter-Strike 2 is a worthy successor to the acclaimed franchise, combining the classic gameplay elements that fans know and love with innovative features that push the genre forward. Whether you're a longtime fan of the series or a newcomer looking for an adrenaline-fueled shooter, Counter-Strike 2 delivers an unforgettable gaming experience that will keep you coming back for more.

Refrain from buying prime status if you simply want to enjoy the game with friends on a more stable environment. I bought the prime status to potential play with my friends on its original price and the game started matching me games with bad pings, worse teammates, and somehow more horrendous gaming performance (rubber banding, shots not registering, throw-able delays, etc). Not to mention you also need to grind to unlock prime % to play in the mode you paid for. 

If you bought it and intend to refund it, don't accept any free cosmetic items as this will lead to steam refusing your refund. There's a chance you might earn back the money through skins, but the process will be akin to forced labor with the same old game play, poor performance and shitty game policies. On a side note, play other games for better quality time as most players in this game are either too poor to buy better pcs and games or are young enough to waste their time in cyber cafes

^ this was my review for CS:GO

As for CS2... what a dogshit experience; rubber-banding players and saying they are sitting below 30 ms. Don't bother with 'skill based matchmaking' unless you have 4 or 5 to a party because you will get unranked enemies that one tap every round and teammates that don't wear headsets or microphones.

Want to land shots? Well CS2 will have you standing still against a still enemy and once you aim for the head and shoot a bullet it will miss, yet the trail will show it going through the enemy.  But rest assured, the enemy will be able to headshot your team while running no matter the angle :)

Want to kick a random that is AFK or throwing? Can't do that if you're queued as 4 people because then the person doing the griefing won't get a say in the vote.... makes sense

Have confidence in VAC? One of my best friends gets reported and banned within a 5 minute period for aim assist at 4 kills round 20+ using an auto-shotgun. Don't worry though, all of those level 1-4 steam accounts with no hours headshotting your team the whole game won't be penalized for anything like THAT.

TLDR: CS:GO is dead and Valve killed it for a clearly worse experience... good thing there's a new case though, right?
