In my opinion, Counter Strike 2 has been a mixed bag. One the one hand, the game looks amazing, the new smoke grenades are really cool to play with, and the gameplay feels largely unchanged, apart from the new subtick system. On the other hand, we've lost a lot of things from CS:GO, such as easy in-game access to workshop maps, changing the bot difficulty for bot matches, and even most console commands that a lot of people use, such as cl_righthand and cl_bob. Not to mention the wide raft of bugs and glitches that came with this "full launch". If you ask me, it feels like the Counter Strike community is taking part in a forced public beta of Counter Strike 2. I would honestly wait until Valve fixes a lot of the bugs in the game, which may take quite a while, knowing Valve.

Edit 11/10/2023:
With the update a few days ago, the game feels a lot better to play. I feel like my shots are going where they're supposed to, and I'm pleased with the progress that Valve has made in terms of making the game playable. However, key features from CS:GO are still missing, such as cl_righthand and cl_bob. Workshop support has been finally introduced to CS2, and in my experience works well. I am still a bit hard pressed to recommend CS2 at this stage of the game's lifespan. I would encourage new players to wait for one or two more large updates before playing, or ideally holding off until the first CS2 Operation comes out. But it is playable at this stage.

Edit 2: 2/14/2024:
The game plays a lot better after the Arms Race update, but now there are issues with lower frame rates and more lag. Also, cl_righthand and cl_bob are still absent, but this could be due to Valve trying to make things more equal, or potentially trying to add it into the settings menu, rather than have it be confined to the console. Either way, Valve has been rather slow to fix the game and/or add new content, but the important thing is that fixes and new content are both in the works.

CS was the best game I ever played when I started on 1.4.  I played all the way to 1.6 and had a blast (tho nades acted diff in 1.6 and took a long time getting used to but whatever).  Then years later GO comes out and you restrict aim on weapons and some of the features the original had.  It felt like you just took some of the heart and soul out of the game and gave us a zombie version.  Still playable and recognisable, but not what we loved and wanted to continue playing.  Years later we come to today where I paid 20 bucks for the premium of CS2 and I wasted my money.  This is awful.  The summary is:

 "Play a game with 2 teams that dont matter bc its all free for all and your guy is a simple who can't aim down gun sights or run fast and are stuck in a basic limited version of our once glorious game".  

All the franchise and history behind this game and in it's now current form I'd have to say i feel sad and embarrassed for the dev team.  Maybe good things should come to an end and fade away.  God knows I wont see another half life game out before I pass but wow Alyx was super duper so maybe thats a good thing. All you did was make a game based on an older version of one of your games and then strip it down until its broken and pointless and has no essence of the original aside from copying the maps.  Anyways, don't buy this, this game is awful.  I would suggest an actual shooter with actual game modes for near the same price, or free.  Most anything from the last decade will have these features and not be a clone of something in its former glory.  Stay away, dont buy unless they ever add actual game modes other then free for all....like, you have free for all but you load in as 2 teams?  Fix and finish your game.

CS2 from 2023
CS2 certainly has its moments. The gameplay is often exhilarating, providing an intense experience for fans of the genre. The variety of maps and game modes keeps things fresh and engaging. Additionally, the selection of weapons and equipment is impressive, allowing players to find their own playstyle.

The graphics and sound are also well-executed. The visuals are appealing and contribute to immersion, while the soundtrack and effects enhance the game's tension.

But to be honest, all the good is overshadowed by the presence of cheaters. It's frustrating to play against individuals who cheat and manipulate the game to win. It undermines the integrity of the game and makes it difficult to truly enjoy. It's disappointing to see that the development team isn't doing much to address this issue.

Overall, my opinion of CS2 is mixed. It has great potential, but the presence of cheaters makes it difficult to fully enjoy. I really hope the development team can address this problem better in the future because the game has the potential to be truly great.

Introduction:
CS2 is a highly anticipated sequel to the critically acclaimed CS1, promising advanced features, improved performance, and an enhanced user experience. In this review, we'll delve into the key aspects of CS2 and evaluate its strengths and weaknesses.

User Interface:
CS2 boasts a sleek and intuitive user interface, making navigation and task execution seamless. The redesigned layout enhances productivity, with customizable options catering to diverse user preferences. However, some users may find the learning curve steep initially.

Features:
CS2 introduces a plethora of new features, including enhanced code analysis tools, advanced debugging capabilities, and seamless integration with popular development frameworks. The addition of AI-driven code suggestions and automated refactoring tools streamlines development workflows, significantly boosting productivity. However, the sheer breadth of features may overwhelm novice users, necessitating comprehensive training and support.

Performance:
CS2 exhibits commendable performance improvements over its predecessor, with faster compilation times, reduced memory footprint, and smoother execution of resource-intensive tasks. The optimized codebase ensures swift responsiveness, even when handling large-scale projects. However, occasional performance bottlenecks may arise under heavy workloads, requiring periodic optimization and fine-tuning.

Compatibility:
CS2 maintains backward compatibility with CS1 projects, facilitating seamless migration for existing users. Furthermore, cross-platform support ensures compatibility with a wide range of operating systems and development environments, enhancing flexibility and accessibility. However, compatibility issues with certain third-party plugins or libraries may arise, necessitating proactive troubleshooting and updates.

Community Support:
CS2 benefits from a vibrant and active community of developers, fostering collaboration, knowledge sharing, and continuous improvement. Online forums, documentation resources, and user groups provide invaluable support, helping users overcome challenges and unlock the full potential of the platform. Additionally, regular updates and bug fixes demonstrate the developer's commitment to addressing user feedback and enhancing product quality.

Conclusion:
CS2 stands as a formidable successor to CS1, offering a compelling suite of features, improved performance, and robust community support. While the learning curve and occasional performance issues may pose challenges, the overall experience is highly rewarding for developers seeking a powerful and versatile coding environment. With its innovative tools and collaborative ecosystem, CS2 sets a new standard for modern software.

I've played CSGO on and off since its conception and this is not a game for beginners dude. People have been playing this game for years and have countless hours into this game and the previous iterations of counter strike and will just annihilate you. Whether that be from skill, cheating, or you just sucking; you won't have very much fun. 

The state of the game now (at the time of review) is not as complete as the players were hoping for. It's missing half the maps CSGO had and other niche things like Overwatch. Valve will (hopefully) add the rest of the components in over time but as of right now the game itself, is complete; just not as complete and polished like CSGO. It has the popular maps, all the guns, and skins that players typically care the most about; its just not at its full potential. Which is annoying for a lot of players too including myself, but, at least we can still play it.

The cheating also described in other reviews is not exaggerated either. There are a substantial amount of noticeable cheaters. More than in CSGO. I really don't know why that is; I'm not a game developer or a cheat software engineer or a cheat seller/user. All I know is that I see much more memorable cheating in CS2 as opposed to when CSGO was around. I'm hoping Valve does whatever they need to do to remedy that faster than they have been moving so far. Don't say I didn't warn you. 

Given all that information, I still do enjoy this game. It's still counter strike and will always be a marvel for FPS's world wide for years to come. No matter how clunky, goofy, glitchy, or aggravating, it will always be fun. Valve will continue to improve on it patch after patch until its finally complete. I will always come back to counter strike for some good ol' fashioned janky hitbox fun. But if you're new or returning, don't let the bad reviews or what I said discourage you. Just play it. If you hate it, just uninstall. The game is free for crying out loud.

I recently made a comeback to CSGO. I didn't get the invite to the beta, but I was hyped for the release of CS2.

Let's dive:

Sub-tick rate feels like a joke right now. Movement is clumsy, running with mates to the same place as terrorists feels like garbage. Dropping bomb, guns and grenades feels wrong. Insane peeker advantage. Spraying and tapping feels bad.

The audio is not on par with CSGO. Definitely needs some improvement, but it's still miles ahead of Valorant's, or should I say, leagues better.

Lack of QoL. I never could get into COD, because of all the handshaking. I'm not starring in a rap music video to throw my hands everywhere. It's not THAT bad, but I would love to see me some cl_bob action in a console.

The last point is optional, I can see where Valve is going with this. They're trying to create the same experience for everybody. I absolutely love the new jump-throw mechanic. Lack of r_cleardecals feels like a right choice, that is if the blood splatters and bodies are the same on every client. The follow recoil option on a crosshair is a nice touch.

I never really liked faceit that much. The idea of splitting the community that way is wrong. But matchmaking felt unrewarding. You get the Global Elite and that's it. Boring. That's why I love the new CS rating. And would've loved it even more if I haven't been playing vs 5-man stacks. I understand that it's not as severe as playing vs a 5-man stack in Dota, but, for the love of GabeN, add a strict solo queue. And make it so the Enter button would accept a game.

I see a lot of people ain't happy. From the release date up to right now CS2 got around 60% positive reviews on Steam. They want to see Arms Race, Danger Zone, Mac support, Achievements. I say fuck all that.

I love Valve for doing the groundbreaking work, for supporting Linux, for Steam, for the memes. I wasn't even mad when The Artifact was released. But this time I got hit hard.

I know that Valve will deliver eventually, because they are good at fixing things. But at the time when Dota 2 was released, which I didn't like, I had Warcraft to go back to. Same with CSGO and CSS. This time I have a broken game that I don't wanna play. And that's a pity.

Actually, now that I've used my brain power to put thoughts into writing, I'm not mad anymore and will be leaving a positive review on Steam. Cya in Premier.

Title: Counter-Strike: Global Offensive - A Timeless Masterpiece in Competitive Gaming

Introduction:
Counter-Strike: Global Offensive, commonly known as CS:GO, stands as a testament to the enduring appeal of tactical first-person shooters. Developed by Valve Corporation and Hidden Path Entertainment, this iconic title has solidified its place in the esports pantheon since its release in 2012. As we delve into the intricacies of CS:GO, it becomes evident why this game remains a cornerstone in the competitive gaming landscape.

Graphics and Art Direction:
CS:GO might not boast the hyper-realistic graphics of some contemporary titles, but its visual style is deliberate and effective. The minimalist approach allows players to focus on the gameplay, with clean and easily distinguishable character models and environments. The art direction strikes a balance between realism and playability, contributing to the game's timeless aesthetic.

Gameplay:
At its core, CS:GO is an unparalleled experience in tactical gameplay. The emphasis on teamwork, strategy, and precise gunplay sets it apart from other shooters. The game features two distinct factions, terrorists and counter-terrorists, each with unique objectives. Rounds are intense, short, and demand split-second decision-making, creating a palpable sense of tension that keeps players on the edge of their seats.

Weapons and Economy:
The weapon system in CS:GO is a masterpiece of balance. From pistols to sniper rifles, each firearm serves a specific purpose, requiring players to make strategic choices based on their team's economy and the current round situation. The economy system, where players earn money for kills and objectives, adds a layer of depth, forcing teams to carefully manage their resources for the best chance of success.

Maps:
CS:GO boasts a diverse map pool, each with its own distinct layout and challenges. Classic maps like Dust II and Mirage continue to be fan favorites, while new additions like Vertigo and Overpass bring refreshing changes to the competitive landscape. The map design encourages varied strategies, ensuring that no two matches feel the same.

Esports Integration:
CS:GO has become synonymous with competitive gaming, with a thriving esports scene that has captivated millions worldwide. Major tournaments, such as the ESL One series and the ELEAGUE Major, draw massive viewership, showcasing the game's enduring appeal and providing a platform for top-tier teams and players.

Community and Modding:
One of CS:GO's strengths lies in its robust community and modding support. The Steam Workshop allows players to create and share custom maps, skins, and game modes, fostering creativity and community engagement. The support for third-party competitive platforms like Faceit and ESEA further extends the game's lifespan beyond casual play.

Conclusion:
Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is a timeless masterpiece that has withstood the test of time in the ever-evolving landscape of gaming. Its emphasis on skill, strategy, and teamwork, coupled with a thriving esports scene and a dedicated community, solidifies its status as a quintessential title in the first-person shooter genre. As CS:GO continues to evolve with updates and new content, it remains a must-play for both seasoned veterans and newcomers looking to experience the pinnacle of competitive gaming.

As a long-time fan of the Counter-Strike franchise, diving into Counter Strike 2 was an exhilarating experience that seamlessly blended nostalgia with modern gameplay mechanics. Developed as the much-anticipated successor to the iconic Counter-Strike: Global Offensive (CS:GO), this latest installment in the series undoubtedly brings a fresh coat of paint to the beloved formula.

One of the most striking aspects of Counter Strike 2 is its stunning visual overhaul. From meticulously designed maps to intricately detailed character models, every element of the game exudes a level of polish that is hard to ignore. The updated graphics breathe new life into familiar environments, making each match feel more immersive than ever before.

Moreover, Counter Strike 2 introduces a host of new features and gameplay mechanics that add depth and complexity to the classic formula. Whether it's the addition of new weapons, enhanced customization options, or refined movement mechanics, there's no denying that the developers have gone above and beyond to deliver a truly modernized experience.

The game's multiplayer component remains as addictive as ever, offering intense firefights and strategic gameplay that keeps players coming back for more. The revamped matchmaking system ensures balanced matches, while the inclusion of new game modes adds variety and replayability to the experience.

However, despite its many strengths, Counter Strike 2 does fall short in some areas when compared to its predecessor, CS:GO. While the updated visuals are undeniably impressive, they come at the cost of performance optimization, leading to occasional frame drops and stuttering, particularly on lower-end systems.

Furthermore, while the introduction of new gameplay mechanics is appreciated, some fans may argue that they stray too far from the simplicity and purity of the original Counter-Strike experience. In particular, certain changes to weapon balancing and movement mechanics may alienate longtime players who prefer the more straightforward approach of CS:GO.

In conclusion, Counter Strike 2 is a worthy successor to the iconic franchise that introduces a wealth of new content and features while retaining the core elements that made its predecessors so beloved. While it may not surpass the greatness of Counter-Strike: Global Offensive in every aspect, it nonetheless stands as a testament to the enduring legacy of the series and a must-play for fans of competitive first-person shooters.

A game with full of cheaters

Counter-Strike 2 brings the beloved classic into the modern era with upgraded graphics and refined gameplay mechanics, revitalizing the timeless formula for a new generation of players.

While the core gameplay remains faithful to its roots, Counter-Strike 2 introduces enhancements that inject fresh energy into the iconic franchise.

However, there are still areas that could benefit from improvement. For solo players, facing full five-stack teams can be a frustrating experience, underscoring the need for better matchmaking algorithms to ensure more balanced matches. Additionally, occasional FPS drops, even on high-end hardware such as the Nvidia RTX 3090, detract from an otherwise seamless gaming experience.

On a positive note, recent updates have finely tuned the sub-tick system, resulting in the most refined gun-play among all Counter-Strike iterations.

The addition of new smokes and loadout features enriches the strategic depth of the game, offering players additional avenues for tactical mastery.

Overall, Counter-Strike 2 maintains its status as a premier competitive shooter, delivering intense tactical gameplay that continues to captivate players worldwide. While there are still areas for improvement, the game's enduring appeal and dedicated player base solidify its position as a cornerstone of the esports landscape.

Counter Strike Global Offensive was my favorite game. I have spent thousands on this game, what a waste. I used to believe that the producers of this game cared about the end product they were serving and I eagerly awaited CS2's release. I enjoyed short access to the beta and enjoyed its general release, however there is a point where the polish washes away, all the new visuals disappear. Suddenly, you are playing a worse knock off version of what we had in CSGO. Don't get me wrong, I recall the bugs that CSGO had and still has! However, it is clear to me with the reckless updates of CS2, how standoffish and cold Valve treats CS2, and the only true content since release also including a Case, that Valve has no care if CS2 is enjoyable, only if its profitable. Clearly this new case is generating huge revenue for the game. A game that is no where near the state of the game that you have taken from us. A game we all paid for. You have played us all for fools. What you need funds to help the production of in-complete content? Broken Updates? Shame on you for this incompetently put together product.

It can be fun, it can be toxic, and getting matched with a good group who are funny and toxic makes it a different game entirely. It's taken a few different forms, but this year in November Counter-Strike will be 24 years old and there is absolutely a reason it's been around so goddamn long.  I've been a casual for maybe 15 years with this game, and don't see myself stopping. The developers even (sometimes) listen to the community, and implement the changes they want (eventually...) if they're meme'd on hard enough. Counter Strike is an enigma, and I hope it continues to improve as time goes on. Even though we'll never see a CS 3, as Valve cannot count that high.

Devs: I wanna see all the old popular maps get a makeover for CS 2, and PLEASE make a Dust 3 (April Fools joke...?)

Unfortunately, all the successor to CS:GO achieved is worse performance, glitchier gameplay, and terrible movement and spray patterns. This shooter was never about graphics, and could've very much done with less changes to gameplay, of which there weren't many meaningful ones, just annoying differences.

Also, the premiere matchmaking system in its current form is bad. Every game feels like a coin toss, where you rarely get a match with people of equal skill.

This is it. I was a diehard CSGO fan, I loved everything about it. When CS2 got announced, I was hyped more than anything. They really blew it. From the lackluster release up to now, I always gave them the benefit of the doubt, I always tried to get back into it. It truly is one of the biggest disappointments I got to experience in my life. This is it.

It's just really sad what this game has become. I literally write this with tears in my eyes because there are so many great memories and friends I associate with this game. It really was a part of me. 
Coming back from school to play CSGO with your friends, Getting my buddy's AK redline because I bought him food once, getting scammed on some random third party site as a 14-year old because I wanted to do these trade-up challenges, joining a shitty clan with wonderful people to try to get better, learning nade lineups until 3am to instantly forget most of them, all the randoms I connected with along the way, all the clutches I shadowplayed thinking I was the next S1mple. Creating a second account and sharing it with my friends, all the hours playing hide-and-seek, my word-file where I wrote down all the dream inventories I wished I could affort, all of my favorite YouTubers and Pro-Players. Dropping to Silver Elite Master which unironically became a long lasting meme within my friendgroup, to then finally reach Global after 2000+ hours. I even wanted to tattoo the bomb code on my arm god dammit. 

And it all got taken away from me just like that. It's so over, my life has peaked a long time ago.

I don't care if you call me old-fashioned, I don't care if CS2 is plenty successful, I don't care about any other opinion, the game is dead to me. 

At long last, goodbye CSGO.
I was pressured into spending money and now im not allowed to stop playing

CS2 is definitely in a better space than when it was released. Now, they need to fix the community. They have tools to do this in Dota 2, but the NEED to stop thinking that they can't reuse system from dota 2 and just use them. Things like behavior score should definitely be added into this game.

_______________________________________________________________________
PREVIOUS REVIEW

CS2 released in open beta, but Valve felt pressure to call it a game release because they announced a deadline that they couldn't meet. The problem is that they didn't push the deadline back, and as we have seen many times in the past like 5 or so years, gamers would rather have a FINISHED game then a buggy mess that will age well. If only you guys had put this game up for open beta, and fixed the bugs that we had known about since closed beta, this wouldn't be that big of a deal. Like how are the physics in your engine inconsistent?

I'm not sure "2" was the right name choice here. Coincidentally, it's like a 2 out of 5.

For some reason, CS2 just feels like a repackaged CS:GO for hardcore players who loved that and didn't want it to change at all. The shooting feels cleaner and the game is prettier with some better load times, but there's nothing new as far as content goes outside of the loadout system, which essentially boils down to restricting your gun selections while in-game, outside of the ability to take both variants of the M4. Valve had the chance to offer a rating system and anti-cheat that solidified it as the premier competitive shooter choice, but instead VAC got mass-cracked before the game even came out and cheating is running as rampant as ever before. On top of that, now it requires you to WIN 10 games on each map before you're rated for that map and that map only, so you're at the mercy of playing absolute killers on their unranked 4th account until you can pull off some wins. This may take longer than you remember, as the "short match" option has been removed from competitive games, as have many of the other game modes that you could just play instead. There is no carry-over rank from CS:GO despite this being basically the same game. There are no new maps or weapons, and changes to existing weapons seem non-existent, with many guns are still feeling pointless.

If your intention is to stand by a franchise you've been playing for decades (no matter what) or to become the next great eSports shooter pro, I'm sure you'll love this. If that's not you, there's competitors who offer much better experiences. Counter-Strike 2 will most likely be continue to be the leading competitive FPS for hardcore players due to it's history, but it's probably going to be a hard pass for most people looking for something new to play.

Original Review (CS:GO - Recommended):
Counter-Strike: Global Offensive adds a much-needed component to an otherwise long-lasting and fun action game: accessibility! The addition of Deathmatch, Arms Race (unofficially better known as "Gun Game"), and Demolition help new players acclamate themselves to the weapons and team dynamics found in more traditional competitive modes. While matchmaking's fun, there's still a server browser, for those of you craving custom maps, rules and play modes.

Sadly, they added cosmetics. And while it's helping keep Valve in business, it ultimately adds nothing to the game, minus community members who try to grind through matches (i.e. "Just let playerX win.") whenever a new chest is released. Oh, and a lot of the CS community is *still there,* though in a gesture of acknowledgement of how troll-filled competitive shooters can get, muting players has never been easier.

That being said, CS:GO is a solid entry in an excellent franchise for new and old players alike.

EDIT: CS2 has unfortunately changed my review from positive to negative. I kept playing legacy as long as I could in private and community servers, but valve has now forced us into its shoddily designed sad excuse for a AAA game.

CS:GO is a very famous game. Almost everyone has heard of it and considering how old it is I was always surprised by the continued popularity compared with modern giants such as CoD, BF, etc.

So recently I decided to try out the game (I owned it for a while before I actually started playing it). Instantly I can see why this is one of the few games that will last decades. CS:GO is a classic Close Quarters Battle game. It features a number of fun game modes (from deathmatch to hostage rescue), it has a lot of well designed maps (with news ones always being addded), and it has all the great weapons that every shooting video game needs.

However, one thing clearly marks this game far above its competitors: its mechanics. The game design and shooting mechanics offer ease of use, realism, and a learning curve which allows growth in skill as you play. It is a fine balance that has been perfectly executed, unlike many other shooting games I have played. Playing on small maps with no vehicles or other additions, the 'shooting' in this game is what defines it, and [b]what makes it the funnest combat game I have played.[/b]

Also worth noting is the community of this game, yesterday when I was on the server there were around 350,000. This game has the 3rd largest user base on steam and 86% of its 3 million reviews are positive which is phenomenal.

Lastly I would like to acknowledge the Dev team which somehow keeps updating the game even though it is nearly 7 years old and now free. And the updates aren't bug-fixes but new content!

EDIT: A long time later, with many more hours and much enjoyment gained: I will not change my positive review but I will add that the match making nowadays is quite poor.

At the time of writing this, CS is in a rough spot. Rampant cheaters every other game, no new content, unbalanced elo loss and gain in premier, peeker's advantage, incorrect bullet registration related to ping differences, the list goes on. 

However, my love for this game never seems to fade. As tilted I am feeling hopeless playing with a cheater, or demotivated because open queue teammates have no mics or are toxic for no reason, that's the state of the game and I have to live with that. I hope Valve is cooking something up with new changes and bringing back Train and perhaps creating other maps for us to enjoy. CS has always been a great tactical shooter game with a need for precision, proper timing, and strategy to be good at. 

Back to the actual review, this is the game to play if you want to get into FPS games. It teaches you to control your recoil, and unlike many other FPS games such as COD and Apex, the less you move the better you shoot. That does not mean movement is unimportant in this game. I will argue is even more important. 

This game will push you to your mental capabilities and technical skills, and you will be rewarded when you win rounds no one thought you could. Even in this state the game is currently in, I will still 100% recommend it for anyone.

Edit (Feb 10, 2024): Valve released the first major update in CS2, and I must say it's in the right step forward. Reducing peaker's advantage, bringing new mechanics in the game such as smokes on shadow (even though it is quite buggy right now), and movable stickers and changes to the Zeus, are all changes that I see as for the better. If Valve continues to cook I believe we will be served a great version of CS.

I used to list this game as recommended, and now I cannot in clear conscience do so, which forces me to issue a complete edit of my CSGO review, with the CS2 addendum.

My original CSGO review: Best CS ever. Which unfortunately means it's still CS, and it comes with all the legacy CS baggage... As in: Frequent crap bullet reg along with enemies hitting you before you can see them, and this means your connection is f'd, which won't get better for at least a week. Cheaters out the wazzoo, going on 23 years strong and counting. So half the time it's FU CS, even if you're somehow winning. I question why I play this game every time I do, and I feel on the verge of quitting for good just as often.

CS2 early review: Well it's out, and it's dog crap, improving smoke and nothing else. And maybe, other players have had a different experience, but mine has been dog crap. The hit reg is dog crap. The performance on a high end PC has been dog crap. Overall, I was having a tough day, and then I stepped in dog crap.

Oh, and how about all those CSGO achievements you spent years working on and earning? Well they don't mean a damn thing anymore, since they're gone for good along with the game you might've wanted to continue playing, and you never had a choice.

I honestly had more fun with CS in the first betas, and then up to 1.5, where 1.6 and beyond never felt the same, and I've been hoping for that original feeling ever since. CS2 is not that thing, and it basically sucks in it's current state.

Edit 02/10/24: The BIG F'ING UPDATE is out, so the game HAS to be better, right? Nope. Hit reg has NOT improved, and I see a serious issue with data reg in general, where in fact the 2 times I decided to pick up a weapon towards the end of a round only to find that what I ACTUALLY DID AND SAW HAPPEN didn't actually happen, and I still had the same gun in my hand from 3 seconds ago. Of course this problem manifested itself in multiple enemies not receiving damage at all from clear hits over and over. This game is still a flaming dumpster of poop, even stinking when I'm not playing it.

[Scene: The living room of the Banks mansion. Uncle Phil, Aunt Vivian, Will, Carlton, Ashley, Geoffrey, Jazz, and Hilary are gathered around the TV. The room is filled with anticipation as Uncle Phil prepares to play Exit Kun.]

Uncle Phil: [Holding the controller] Alright, everyone, it's time for me to show you how it's done. I'm going to conquer this game like I conquer the courtroom!

Will: [Grinning] Oh, Uncle Phil, you sure you're up for the challenge? This game's got more twists than one of your legal cases!

Uncle Phil: [Smirking] Don't underestimate me, Will. I've got the eye of an eagle and the reflexes of a panther.

Carlton: [Excitedly] Go get 'em, Dad! Show 'em who's boss!

Uncle Phil: [Proudly] That's the spirit, son.

[Aunt Vivian chuckles as Uncle Phil starts the game. The screen flickers to life with vibrant colors and quirky characters.]

Geoffrey: [Dryly] Oh, I do hope this game doesn't test your patience too much, sir. It seems rather... stimulating.

[Ashley and Hilary walk into the room, curious about the commotion.]

Ashley: What's going on? Is Dad playing another one of his video games?

Will: [Grinning] You got it, Ash. He's trying to conquer this one, but it's giving him a run for his money.

Hilary: [Smirking] Oh, this I have to see. Dad, don't break the controller this time!

[A few minutes pass as Uncle Phil encounters his first anomaly in the game, followed by another, and then another.]

Will: [Smirking] Looks like Uncle Phil's legal eagle eyes are struggling with this one.

Carlton: [Excitedly] Go, Dad, you can do it!

[Jazz interjects with his usual flair.]

Jazz: [Laughing] Yo, Uncle Phil, you're slower than a snail in molasses! Let me show you how it's done.

Uncle Phil: [Annoyed] Jazz, I've got this under control. No need for your... expertise.

[Jazz starts backseat gaming, offering unsolicited advice and commentary as Uncle Phil's frustration grows.]

Jazz: [Laughing] C'mon, Phil, you gotta be quicker than that! Even Carlton's dance moves are faster than your progress in this game!

[Will, Carlton, and Ashley exchange amused glances.]

Carlton: [Whispering to Ashley] Dad's got this, right? He's just warming up.

[Geoffrey maintains his composure, observing the chaos with his usual dry wit.]

Geoffrey: [Sipping tea] It appears the game has proven to be quite the challenge, much like trying to teach a fish to ride a bicycle.

[Uncle Phil's temper reaches its boiling point as Jazz continues to tease him with his antics.]

Uncle Phil: [Furious] That's it! I've had enough of your nonsense, Jazz.

[Without hesitation, Uncle Phil strides over to Jazz, grabs him by the waist, and hurls him through the nearby open window.]

Jazz: [Screaming] Uncle Phil!

[The room falls into a momentary stunned silence as Jazz sails out of sight and crashes onto the lawn outside.]

Will: [Laughing] Classic Uncle Phil move!

[The family bursts into laughter as Uncle Phil closes the window with a satisfied smirk.]

Uncle Phil: [Smirking triumphantly] Now, where were we? Ah, yes, conquering this game like a true champion.

[The family settles back, enjoying the spectacle of Uncle Phil's gaming prowess, as the screen fades to black.]

This game is just about as stable as a junkie on heroin.

The game can still fun for casual experience, but has a lot of broken parts which spoil said experience. After all, having a pretty light modern game (baked-in lightning, no heavy geometry and shading etc.) dipping below 80 fps on a recent nvidia GPU is... disappointing, to say the least. Especially considering that before CS2, we had CSGO that ran just fine and didn't make it so that the performance goes on to have "bad trip" after an update.

I'm glad that Arms Race has made its way back into the game after almost a year of waiting, but not having monastery or lunacy available to play on is... rather disappointing.

The entire migration to Source 2 thus far feels... disappointing. And I've been defending it for over 8 months at this point.

I really don't like how you have to equip weapons before games. Most people don't use that many weapons; but still, I see no benefit in limiting player choice in a match. It just makes the game more boring. Part of counter strike was the weapon buying. This just removes choice and any realism brought by that aspect. 

Like why are these people limited on what they can buy. Do these Ts and CTs need to have specific licenses for each weapon and can only carry so many on them at a time? It just doesn't make sense from a gameplay or lore perspective. Adds nothing, limits everything. 

Random tangent but seriously who thought this was a good idea? Maybe choice overwhelms them? Otherwise if this was for UI, ughh, bad game devs, bad. Why would you ever sacrifice gameplay for UI? Add every gun to the gun store and the game would be better; to be honestly blunt.

An Updated Review, I'm only playing this because I am having fun with friends and not directly attributed with the game-play provided.

The release and update to CS2 has been more than underwhelming at most,

1) Increasing the need of compute resource to run Valve's new source 2 engine, albeit better has killed majority of the players on low end gaming personal computers of the past.

2) The removal of past achievements tied to CS:GO was disheartening to watch as a singular global achievement sits at the very pedestal of what memories it used to hold.

3) As a fairly new replacement of the counter-strike franchise, it has failed miserably in porting and migration of the vast maps and game modes it had carried in it's predecessors wake. Taking it several months before the official release of match download was available (Disappointing for a "Competitive" game).

4) Fall of Anti-Cheat, Hype buzzwords of AI to deem an upgrade to anti-cheat is marketing sham at best. As someone who worked in Data and AI industry, you run into common problem of zero-shot learning (data-less learning) to identity new cheating behavioral patterns. Leaving more cheaters rampant for long.

After putting years of my life into this game. I can say truthfully, that this game is quite fun. Playing games with friends has always been a must for me. Without friends, I don't think I would have put so many hours into this as I have. Most community servers are good for a laugh and the Competitive gamemode is mostly filled with nice players.

However. The main downside to this game is the community. Though the game is fun to play with friends and good overall community gamemode servers. Both official Competitive and Casual modes are (in my opinion) unbearable. The toxic nature of these games has pushed me away from playing as of late. But I wouldn't blame that for me loosing interest in the game.

Overall. CSGO is a great game to have a mess around on with friends and for a quick fix of Competitive gameplay. My only words of wisdom regarding this game, is be ready to mute a lot of your team in Casual matchmaking.

CSGO:
Pros: Fun game, simple goals and huge player base; Lots of skins and content.

Cons: Ranking system is useless until MG3+; Hackers common at lower ranks; far too many smurf accounts.

That being said; Comp play is exceptionally difficult at lower ranks due to so many people having multiple accounts and general salty people that think they're pro. The plus side to that is that it's hilarious hearing them sound off and get mad.

Counter Strike has been a Genre defining series since the inception of the half life mod. It has been they competitive first person shooter. This is not mindless arcade call of duty(post cod4 promod) style. It is almost as much of a mind game as a mechanically intensive "Easy to learn. Hard to master" mantra that Valve seems to like so much. 
    I will not be speaking of the more casual players that only plan on playing respawn game modes or 10v10's. I will be speaking for people that enjoy playing games in a competitive format that are willing to learn and put time into games with high skill caps.
      here is a fair warning, if you hate not being the best at something, this might not be the game for you. You have to put a lot of time into this game to be good. I have almost 800 hours on this game at the time I am writing this review, and I am Legendary Eagle in the rankings, and I still think that I am not good at all. Most of the pro's have been playing the counter strike series for almost ten years or more. So be prepared to never be the best if you are starting now.
   
  I wrote that back in 2015. I now have around 3.5k hours across all my accounts. Though there are many good things about the game, there are better options in 2024 for the north american community. Cheating is still plaguing the game 9 years since I started playing if you want to just boot up the game and  play a few games. The community is so toxic and I can't play it outside of a 5 stack anymore. The new premier matchmaking system also needs a ton of work. You would be better served playing valorant for a 1 to 1 replacement, not that val is perfect by any stretch. I can not recommenced getting into the game as a new player.

CS2 is the only game where people can complain about "cheaters" and a "broken anti-cheat" but then continue to play it and actively support Valve with case openings

Counter Strike : Global Offensive was undoubtedly a better game than CS 2 and could probably have supported most of the major game changes that have come. The new graphics are a quite cartoonish, unlike the old game. 

However it's still too nostalgic to let go of.

The amount of people using walls and/or soft aim assist in this game has become ridiculous. If investments are not made quickly to combat the issue, pvp first person shooters will become a thing of the past. 

It is to the point now that players using cheats will join the same team/party to guarantee a win as they know they could end up matched against other cheaters.  

I have dumped 650 hours into this game and enjoyed much of it; however, for the past year- the cheating issue has become absurd.

Hailed as the pinnacle of tactical first-person shooters, Counter-Strike 2 is the darling of the gaming world. Its intense gunplay, strategic depth, and vibrant/vulgar community keep players coming back for more, year after year. But everything changed with the arrival of this fateful update ‚Äì the update that shattered the dreams of its loyal fan-base, "A Call To Arms".

It began innocently enough. The developers promised a major overhaul, teasing new features, improved gun models, and exciting gameplay tweaks. Players eagerly awaited the update, THEN, it happened.

Excitement turned to disbelief, and disbelief turned to outrage. The once-beloved game was unrecognizable. The entire sticker system has been changed in ways that disrupted the delicate balance of sticker crafts. It was re-balanced to the point of absurdity, turning once-reliable crafts into useless toys.

The community erupted in protest. Forums and social media platforms became battlegrounds as players voiced their discontent. Some demanded immediate rollbacks, while others called for heads to roll within the development team.

But the worst was yet to come. Behind the scenes, whispers spread of more sinister motives behind updates that are yet to come. Rumors swirled of corporate greed driving the decision-making process ‚Äì of developers pressured to prioritize profit over player satisfaction.

And so, the saga of Counter-Strike 2's bad update served as a cautionary tale ‚Äì a reminder of the delicate balance between artistic vision, corporate interests, and player satisfaction in the ever-evolving world of gaming.
